column7: CBA aims to incorporate leading sustainable design principles across energy, water, indoor air quality and waste in its office refurbishments.
In CBA's lending portfolio, water use is the primary nature-related impact for almost all sectors. Soil and water pollution, as well as solid waste, were also prominent themes.
CBA's water consumption includes tenanted usage from CBA and Bankwest commercial buildings and data centres under the Group's operational control in Australia.

CBA's water usage is based on invoiced amounts and estimates based on an average usage per m2 of net lettable area. It includes invoiced water use for the two data centres under the Group's operational control.
CBA consumed 152,791 kilolitres of water in 2023.

column6: Operational sites owned, leased, managed in, or adjacent to, protected areas and areas of high biodiversity value outside protected areas
Significant impacts of activities, produces, and services on biodiversity

column7: CBA's scope 1 emissions in 2023 were 7,891 tCO2e.
CBA's scope 2 emissions in 2023 were 12 tCO2e.
CBA's scope 3 emissions in 2023 were 60,697 tCO2e.
CBA's emissions intensity in 2023 was 170 kgCO2 per MWh.

column13: This year, CBA financed the Golden Plains Wind Farm in Rokewood, Victoria Ã¢ÂÂ the largest approved wind farm in the state. The wind farm construction accelerates Australia's energy transition and benefits the local community economically.
column20: Golden Plains Wind Farm, energy transition, local community

column13: CBA is supporting West Australian Corn Growers to progress their sustainability goals through investment in land restoration and solar power generation. They are joining the carbon marketplace by regenerating unused land and growing native vegetation as part of a carbon farming project. This new initiative with CBA helps West Australian Corn Growers build upon their sustainability strategy.
column20: West Australian Corn Growers, land restoration, solar power

column13: CBA has a long history of supporting Australian farmers. CBA offers a range of sustainable finance and carbon market solutions, enabling it to continue supporting customers as they seek to transition their farms and businesses to adopt more environmentally sustainable practices. CBA's Agri Green Loan aims to support its farmers to invest in regenerative farming practices, renewable energy generation and other activities designed to improve climate and nature outcomes.
column20: Agri Green Loan, sustainable finance, carbon market solution

column13: CBA partnered with Harvard's Sustainability Transparency Accountability Research (STAR) Lab to fund three Harvard-based researchers and two locally-based research fellows commencing in July 2023. The research aims to use behavioural science to produce insights to explore ways CBA can help its customers and communities understand and take action on climate change. CBA plans to develop interventions to nudge customers to upgrade their homes to increase resilience against major weather events and lower emissions.
column20: Sustainability Transparency Accountability Research, Harvard, behavioural science

column13: CBA is a leading contributor to the Australian Banking Association (ABA)'s Climate Roadmap, focusing on industry and government actions to reach net zero. It includes reducing operational emissions and developing industry frameworks for financed emissions, scenario analysis and disclosures.

In partnership with Greening Australia, CBA invested in Nindethana Seed Service, Australia's largest native seed merchant. The investment is intended to support the expansion of Australia's native seed market and help meet demand from carbon reduction and biodiversity restoration projects. Native seed is a critical input for largeÃ¢ÂÂscale land restoration projects, supporting Australia's biodiversity and unique ecosystems by providing habitat for native wildlife and boosting landscape resilience.
column20: Nindethana Seed Service, Greening Australia, native seed market

column13: CBA uses its productivity mapping tool to assess climate risks associated with agricultural production performance for approximately 55% of its Business Bank agriculture exposures, secured by farmland. The tool assesses grain, livestock and dairy portfolios. It ranks the physical risk of postcode locations across three tiers of productivity (low, moderate or high) based on historical weather patterns and current environmental conditions.
column20: Productivity mapping tool, climate risk, agricultural production

column6: Nitrogen oxides (NOx), sulfur oxides (SOx), and other significant air emissions
column13: CBA provided an innovative financing solution to enable Zenobe to lease 'zero emissions' buses and charging infrastructure to Transport Canberra. The first 12 battery electric buses, combined with the potential purchase of a further 90 electric buses, support Transport Canberra in achieving a fully electric bus fleet by 2040.

column6: Waste generation and significant waste-related impacts
column13: CBA worked with Natcapare specialists in nature intelligence to evaluate key areas of impact and dependency in portfolios such as agriculture. Early areas of focus are land-use change, water stress and soil erosion. Insights from this work can help identify opportunities to better support CBA's customers in improving resiliency and natural outcomes.

This year, CBA updated its Supplier Risk Governance (SRG) tool to enhance its ability to assess supplier environmental practices against CBA policy and commitments. As part of this process, CBA proactively contacted suppliers within higher environmental risk industries to ask them about their climate and nature policies, commitments and emissions targets.
column20: Supplier Risk Governance tool, supplier environmental practice, nature policy
